thread.title: Uhuru might not run for top seat on a JAP ticket: Kiraitu
thread.title_full: Uhuru might not run for top seat on a JAP ticket: Kiraitu

title: Uhuru might not run for top seat on a JAP ticket: Kiraitu
text:
Saturday, October 24, 2015 Uhuru might not run for top seat on a JAP ticket: Kiraitu President Uhuru Kenyatta waves to his supporters at Muthurwa Market in downtown Nairobi with his deputy William Ruto among other leaders on October 9, 2014. The two might not run for the top job on a Jubilee Alliance Party (JAP) ticket in 2017 after all. FILE PHOTO | BILLY MUTAI | NAION MEDIA GROUP In Summary Instead, a new political vehicle for the President and his deputy William Ruto will be formed soon, Meru Senator Kiraitu Murungi, who has been tasked with overseeing the merger of Jubilee affiliate parties, has said. President Kenyatta and Mr Ruto indicated that TNA and URP, which are the key parties in the Jubilee coalition, would be disbanded to join JAP and asked other parties in the ruling team to do so. Mr Murungi said the decision to wind up APK and other Jubilee affiliate parties was arrived at during a meeting that brought together leaders from Mt Kenya East in Nkubu weeks ago. Advertisement More by this Author 
President Uhuru Kenyatta might not run for the top job on a Jubilee Alliance Party (JAP) ticket in 2017 after all. 
Instead, a new political vehicle for the President and his deputy William Ruto will be formed soon, Meru Senator Kiraitu Murungi, who has been tasked with overseeing the merger of Jubilee affiliate parties, has said. 
“In fact, Jubilee Alliance Party, which fielded a candidate in the Kajiado Central by-election, is among the parties to be dissolved,” Mr Murungi told the Sunday Nation. “However, since the name ‘Jubilee’ has become popular and a brand, it might be retained in the new outfit.” 
JAP has often been marketed as the Head of State’s re-election vehicle. 
President Kenyatta and Mr Ruto indicated that TNA and URP, which are the key parties in the Jubilee coalition, would be disbanded to join JAP and asked other parties in the ruling team to do so. 
In an interview, Mr Murungi said that following consultations with Mr Kenyatta and Mr Ruto, plans were on to form a new party. 
He said that he been leading talks together with former Cabinet Minister Noah Wekesa on a weekly basis on the collapse of Jubilee affiliate parties. 
“We need to merge and consolidate into one party for faster and rapid transformation of the country. We have since met political parties’ leaders and we shall soon be meeting the parties’ national executive committees,’ Mr Murungi said. 
Mr Murungi stated that his team would also hold talks with MPs, County Assembly members and grassroots officials before the parties are closed. 
“We have up to December to complete the process of formation of one party. No party has been formed as yet. The merging process is still on. The structures of the new party will be explained later,” Mr Murungi said. 
The Alliance Party of Kenya (APK) leader has however faced criticism from some APK supporters for announcing its dissolution to join JAP. 
APK delegates who met at Meru Sports Club last week criticised Mr Murungi for allegedly failing to consult them. They termed Mr Murungi’s move, which has been supported by a majority of APK top officials and MPs from Mt Kenya East, selfish, undemocratic and backward. 
As a result, the delegates have mandated Meru Governor Peter Munya to form another party by December and vie for presidency in 2022. 
“It is unfortunate the good idea is causing ripples,” Mr Murungi said. 
Mr Murungi said the decision to wind up APK and other Jubilee affiliate parties was arrived at during a meeting that brought together leaders from Mt Kenya East in Nkubu weeks ago. 
He said that elected leaders should not fear that nominations would be rigged if they vied in one umbrella party, saying “we are going to set up a transparent nomination process.” 
He said: “Let them join JAP. Nobody will be unfairly treated. There is no need for people to run away and form new parties”.
